newsitem.title: IRAQ: Turkey talks to Iraq on oil-for-food deals.
newsitem.headline: Turkey talks to Iraq on oil-for-food deals.

text.p: Turkish State Minister Ahmet Cemil Tunc arrived in Baghdad on Monday to discuss increasing trade with Iraq under the oil-for-food deal signed with the United Nations.
Tunc said his country was seeking to extend its trade with Iraq under the U.N. resolution 986 which allows Baghdad to sell oil worth $2 billion over six months to buy food and medicine.
"What we aim now within the scope of (resolution) 986 is to extend our trade and hope that there will be another extension of 986," Tunc told Reuters shortly after arriving in Baghdad.
Under the deal, which went into effect in December, Turkey has a contract to lift 75,000 barrels per day of Iraqi crude.
The bulk of the limited Iraqi oil exports is being shipped through a pipeline to the Turkish terminal of Ceyhan on the Mediterranean.

The Turkish minister said Ankara had asked the U.N. Security Council to allow Turkey to trade food and medicine for Iraqi oil in addition to the 986 resolution. "We will exert utmost efforts to achieve this goal," he said.

Tunc said the Turkish energy minister was expected in Baghdad next month to discuss details of a gas agreement reached by the two countries in December. The pact was concluded in Turkey during a visit by Iraqi Oil Minister Amir Muhammed Rasheed.
Details of the agreement have not been given but Iraqi and Turkish officials said last summer a gas pipeline with annual capacity of 10 billion cubic metres would be built.
The first food shipments under the oil deal arrived in Iraq from Turkey last week. They were white beans, chickpeas and vegetable oil.
Iraq said that from April it would increase the monthly food rations distributed to Iraqis under the oil programme with the U.N.
